Award.AwardTitle: Distributed and Robust Estimation for Cyberphysical Systems using a Nonlinear Consensus Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:

The objective of this project is to design and test nonlinear, robust, and power-aware consensus estimation algorithms for fully distributed cyber-physical systems (CPS). Systems that use a large number of networked sensors with limited transmission range due to power limitations are considered. Such systems have a large number of transmitters that are subject to non-Gaussian impulsive noise and network interference. Robust decentralized distributed sensing will be considered with joint design of the sensing and communication systems with low-power constraints.

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit is in the novel design of distributed nonlinear consensus algorithms to solve parameter estimation problems for CPS applications. Proposed convergence analysis, and variance of the estimators in the presence of these nonlinearities go beyond existing analyses of linear approaches. The research will provide power-aware consensus estimation algorithms with minimal assumptions about the sensing and channel noise through judicious design of nonlinearities. Algorithms will be tested with photo-voltaic array data and a testbed will be developed to address and characterize real-time estimation.

Broader Impact:

The broader impacts are on alternative energy, environmental, infrastructure monitoring, and STEM education. The PIs will design educational software modules that use sensing as a paradigm to illustrate basic concepts in probability and communications at the undergraduate level. Dissemination and education efforts will include computer and mobile-based applications using the award-winning JAVA-DSP software packages. The investigators will also actively recruit students from under-represented minorities to work on the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyberphysical systems (CPS), such as monitored utility-scale photovoltaic arrays, are complex and often require continuous networked sensing and parameter estimation. This research is concerned with CPS systems that use a large number of networked sensors that have limited transmission range due to power limitations. Furthermore, we consider systems with a large number of transmitters that are subject to interference. For such systems, it is imperative that sensing and communication tasks are fully decentralized. This necessitates the joint design of the sensing and communication systems while taking into account low-power constraints. We have designed a suite of nonlinear, robust, and power-aware consensus estimation algorithms for fully distributed consensus systems without fusion centers. We have also designed an 18 kW experimental photo-voltaic (PV) array facility consisting of 104 panels where each panel is equipped with monitoring devices.

With this background, our intellectual merit and broader impact contributions with this project can be summarized as:

Intellectual Merit: The project has developed distributed nonlinear consensus algorithms as a solution to the pressing problems of accurate parameter estimation for CPS systems. The PI has developed nonlinear consensus algorithms such as those that estimate the maximum value of sensed data in a network, or quantiles of the data or other graph signal processing methodologies. Convergence analysis, and accuracy of the estimators has been addressed, and go beyond existing analyses. Algorithms have been considered in the context of our photo-voltaic array data and a testbed. To further itemize the intellectual merit behind our contributions we have developed

1. Distributed algorithms for the determination of outliers using max-consensus methods. These are methods where autonomous agents interact only with their local neighbors to estimate the maximum over the global network of a set of initial measurements. This has been achieved using using approaches using the soft-max function. In another set of results, we have used max-plus algebra to achieve the same goal.

2. Distributed algorithms for estimating the structure of networks are considered. The term “structure” refers to how the sensor nodes are connected, the size of the coverage area and the locations of the nodes. Parameters of interest include spectra of the graph representing the network, degree distributions, and clustering the network based on location information. Learning the structure of the network is useful in distributed optimization methods that rely on so-called diffusion adaptation and consensus algorithms, the convergence speed depends on the connectivity of the network.

3. Design and implementation of the 18kW photo-voltaic array facility. Each of these solar panels embeds sensors, wireless transceivers, and relays that enable continuous monitoring, fault detection, and real-time connection topology changes. The facility enables networked data exchanges
via the use of wireless data sharing with servers, fusion and control centers, and mobile devices. Research done includes developing machine learning methods for fault detection.

Broader Impacts: Applications involving aggregation of data from sensors, which are linked through wireless networks, are ubiquitous. This research and its coupling with the 18 kW PV array facility will have impact in the rapidly expanding areas of cyber-physical systems with broad societal impacts such as alternative energy, environmental, and infrastructure monitoring. The PIs have worked with the IEEE student branch at ASU to interact with undergraduate students during the course of the research.
